awd_titl_txt: Large-Scale Investigations of Quasar Winds with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey-III
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate the ejection of matter from the nuclei of galaxies via quasar winds, the link to accretion of matter into the nuclei, and the feedback between these processes that affects the formation and evolution of typical massive galaxies and larger-scale structures.  The PIs and their students will use data on 150,000 quasars from the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey-III (SDSS-III).   They will study variability in the broad absorption line troughs that characterize quasar winds.  

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students, and postdocs.  Catalogs and data products produced by the research will be publicly released, and the PIs and their students will conduct summer workshops for high-school and middle-school teachers.

The main research activity has been a large-scale survey of quasar
wind variability, specifically those winds observed via rest-frame
ultraviolet absorption lines in Broad Absorption Line (BAL) quasars.

The Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS), part of the 
Sloan Digital Sky Survey-III (SDSS-III), was a five-year program
(2009-2014) that used the 2.5-m SDSS telescope to obtain spectra
for about 1.4 million luminous galaxies as well as about 170,000
quasars at redshifts above 2.15. The resulting quasar spectra,
covering 3600-9800 Angstroms, are valuable for a wide range of
investigations including studies of quasar physics. In addition
to the main BOSS galaxy and quasar surveys, a number of smaller
ancillary BOSS projects were approved that "piggybacked" on the
main surveys. One of these, and the subject of this report, was
focused on moving astronomers from small-sample studies of
multi-year BAL variability to setting large-sample statistical
constraints that can be compared with models of quasar winds.
The basic approach was to re-target about 2100 optically bright
BAL quasars already observed from 2000-2008 by SDSS-I/II. This
uniformly defined sample is about 100 times larger than past
samples that had been used to study BAL variability on multi-year
timescales in the rest frame.

With significant effort, we have analyzed the resulting spectra
of our BAL quasars to study the nature of multi-year BAL variability.
We have used our measurements to investigate topics including BAL
disappearance; BAL emergence; absorption-strength variability as
a function of timescale; BAL acceleration; BAL vs. emission-line
and continuum variability; and the effects of luminosity, quasar
accretion rate, and radio emission on BAL variability. The Ph.D.
thesis of graduate student Nurten Filiz Ak was focused on this
topic, and she won an assistant professorship at Erciyes University
(in her native Turkey) based largely on these efforts. Dr. Kate
Grier, a postdoctoral researcher, was also supported by this grant
in 2014-2015, leading an exciting project on rapid BAL variability.

Several primary papers from this project have now been published and
publicly released. The first reported exciting new results on BAL
disappearance; this paper was also featured in an SDSS-III press
release. The second, a large work, presented a comprehensive
large-sample study of BAL-variability properties on multi-year
timescales. The third is a substantial paper on a remarkable
new class of BAL quasars with redshifted broad absorption lines.
The fourth examines models for BAL winds by assessing coordinated
variations of ionization level, kinematics, and column density;
equatorial disk-wind models are generally well supported. The
fifth investigates remarkable rapid variations of a high-velocity
C IV BAL trough in a quasar that was intensively observed as a part
of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Reverberation Mapping Project.
Furthermore, this NSF support has allowed collaboration on highly
relevant additional projects.
